title: Peace Tower
text:
The Peace Tower (), also known as the Tower of Victory and Peace (), is a focal <a href="Bell%20tower">bell</a> and <a href="clock%20tower">clock tower</a> sitting on the central axis of the <a href="Centre%20Block">Centre Block</a> of the <a href="Canada">Canadian</a> <a href="Parliament%20Hill">parliament buildings</a> in <a href="Ottawa">Ottawa</a>, Ontario. The present incarnation replaced the <a href="Victoria%20Tower%20%28Canada%29">Victoria Tower</a> after the latter <a href="Centre%20Block%23Great%20fire">burned down in 1916</a>, along with most of the Centre Block; only the <a href="Library%20of%20Parliament">Library of Parliament</a> survived. It serves as a <a href="National%20symbols%20of%20Canada">Canadian icon</a> and had been featured prominently on the <a href="Canadian%20twenty-dollar%20bill">Canadian twenty-dollar bill</a> directly adjacent the queen's visage, until the change to polymer.
Characteristics.
Designed by Jean Omer Marchand and <a href="John%20A.%20Pearson">John A. Pearson</a>, the tower is a "<a href="campanile">campanile</a>" whose height reaches 92.2 m (302 ft 6 in), over which are arranged a multitude of <a href="rock%20carving">stone carvings</a>, including approximately 370 <a href="gargoyle">gargoyle</a>s, <a href="grotesque">grotesque</a>s, and <a href="frieze">frieze</a>s, keeping with the <a href="Gothic%20Revival%20architecture%20in%20Canada%23Victorian%20High%20Gothic">Victorian High Gothic style</a> of the rest of the parliamentary complex. The walls are of <a href="Nepean%2C%20Ontario">Nepean</a> sandstone and the roof is of reinforced concrete covered with <a href="copper">copper</a>.
At its base is a <a href="porte-coch%C3%A8re">porte-cochère</a> within four <a href="Arch">equilateral pointed arches</a>, the north of which frames the main entrance of the Centre Block, and the jambs of the south adorned by the <a href="supporters">supporters</a> of the <a href="Arms%20of%20Canada">Royal Arms of Canada</a>. Near the apex, just below the steeply pitched roof, are the tower's 4.8 m (16 ft) diameter clock faces, one on each of the four facades. The mechanical workings of the timepiece were manufactured by the <a href="Verdin%20Company">Verdin Company</a> and are set by the <a href="National%20Research%20Council%20Time%20Signal">National Research Council Time Signal</a>. One level below, running around the circumference of the tower's shaft, is an <a href="observation%20deck">observation deck</a>. This was the highest accessible space in Ottawa until the early 1970s; the Peace Tower dominated the <a href="List%20of%20tallest%20buildings%20in%20Ottawa-Gatineau">Ottawa skyline</a>, as a strict 45.7 m (150 ft) height limit was placed on other buildings. That limit, however, was later rescinded, leading the Peace Tower to lose its distinction as the city's tallest structure. Cantilevered out at each of the four corners of the tower, at the level of the observation platform, are four 2.5 m (8 ft 4 in) long, 75 cm (2 ft 6 in) high, and 45 cm (1 ft 6 in) thick gargoyles made of <a href="Stanstead%2C%20Quebec%20%28township%29">Stanstead</a> grey <a href="granite">granite</a> from Beebe, Quebec.
The tower's flagpole holds symbolic significance, acting as the flagpole of the nation. As such, strict protocol surrounds the display of banners atop the Peace Tower, such as <a href="Half-staff%23Canada">half-masting</a> for national mourning and showing the <a href="Royal%20standards%20of%20Canada%23Sovereign">flag of the sovereign</a>, that of any <a href="Monarchy%20of%20Canada%23Royal%20family%20and%20house">member of the Royal Family</a>, or the <a href="Flag%20of%20the%20Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">flag of the governor general</a>, when any of those persons are present on Parliament Hill.
In 1981, a new inclined elevator was installed. It travels on a 10° angle for the first , shifting its position horizontally , and straight up for the remainder of the climb. The elevator car stays level at all times during its movement because it has a gimbal-mounted double frame. Before the installation of the new elevator, the observatory had been reached by taking first one elevator, then climbing a flight of stairs to a second elevator.
Memorial Chamber.
The Peace Tower was designed by architect <a href="John%20A.%20Pearson">John A. Pearson</a> not only to stand as an architectural feature and landmark, but also to function as a <a href="memorial">memorial</a> to Canadians who had given their lives during the Great War. It thus houses the Memorial Chamber, a vaulted 7.3 m by 7.3 m (24 ft by 24 ft) room directly above the porte-cochere, with <a href="stained%20glass">stained glass</a> windows and various other features illustrating Canada's war record, such as the brass plates made from spent shell casings found on battlefields that were inlaid into the floor, and bore the name of each of Canada's major conflicts during the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. Stone that architect John Pearson personally collected from the main European battlefields where Canadians were killed is included in the floors and walls. Pearson described the room, also called the Memorial Chapel, as a "sacred grove in the middle of the forest."
The stone walls were originally to have been inscribed with the names of all Canada's servicemen and women who had died during the First World War; but, without enough space for all 66,000 names, it was later decided to place <a href="Books%20of%20Remembrance%20%28Canada%29">Books of Remembrance</a> there instead; the books list all Canadian soldiers, airmen, and seamen who died in service of <a href="the%20Crown">the Crown</a>—whether <a href="Monarchy%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">that of Britain</a> (before 1931) or <a href="Monarchy%20of%20Canada">that of Canada</a> (after 1931)—or allied countries in foreign wars, including the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>, the <a href="Nile%20Expedition">Nile Expedition</a> and <a href="Second%20Boer%20War">Boer War</a>, the First World War, the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a>, and the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>. The eight books are displayed in glass cases on seven altars around the chamber, the pages of each book turned at 11 a.m. daily so every name is on display to visitors at least once during each calendar year.
Amidst the carved marble plaques detailing Canadian military involvement since Confederation, five marble plaques on display in the Memorial Room present literary passages. Two plaques contain (in English and French) ""<a href="In%20Flanders%20Fields">In Flanders Fields</a>"" by Canadian physician Lieutenant-Colonel <a href="John%20McCrae">John McCrae</a>. One plaque has an excerpt from French-Canadian author <a href="Gabrielle%20Roy">Gabrielle Roy</a>'s novel "<a href="The%20Tin%20Flute">Bonheur d'occasion (The Tin Flute)</a>". Psalm 139:8-10 from the Bible is etched on another plaque in both French and English. A fifth plaque is inscribed with the moving poem "On Going To The Wars" by Canadian writer <a href="Earle%20Birney">Earle Birney</a>: 
Sculpture.
Various elements within the room were formed with stone quarried from the battlefields of <a href="Europe">Europe</a>: from the United Kingdom came Hoptonwood limestone; from Belgium, black marble for the wall plinths and altar steps, as well as St. Anne marble for the clustered columns that support the <a href="fan%20vault">fan vault</a> ceiling from each corner of the room; and from France, <a href="Ch%C3%A2teau-Gaillard">Château-Gaillard</a> stone for the walls and the vault itself, as well as stone from <a href="Flanders">Flanders</a>' fields. These materials were worked into 700 carved elements by a number of different artists and sculptors under the direction of Ira Lake, who desired to tell not only the complete story of Canada's participation in the First World War, but also to commemorate military units as far back as the 17th century regime of <a href="New%20France">New France</a>.
Around the entrance archway are "The Sword of Victory"—a <a href="Relief%23Bas-relief%20or%20low%20relief">bas-relief</a> above the opening—and two stone lions by Pearson, the modeller Charles Adamson, and the sculptor Cléophas Soucy, each bearing a shield; the shield to the left bears the "Dragon of Destruction" and the date "1914", while that on the right shows the "Dove of Peace" perched on a crown and the date "1918". Within the <a href="Tympanum%20%28architecture%29">tympanum</a> of the <a href="antechamber">antechamber</a>'s arch is the sculpted work by Pearson and Soucy, "The Tunnellers' Friends", which shows representations of animals that served during the war: reindeer, pack mules, carrier pigeons, horses, dogs, canaries, and mice, all above the inscription "THE TUNNELLERS’ FRIENDS, THE HUMBLE BEASTS THAT SERVED AND DIED". Around the <a href="archivolt">archivolt</a> at the other end of the entrance passage are sculpted animals and insects, such as beetles, spiders, lizards, butterflies, rats, hares, bats, birds, frogs, and bees; John Pearson stated that these were to represent the flora and fauna of Canada. The inscription around this arch is an excerpt from John Ceredigion Jones' poem "The Returning Man": "ALL'S WELL FOR OVER THERE AMONG HIS PEERS A HAPPY WARRIOR SLEEPS".
The walls of the Memorial Chamber are divided into 17 <a href="Niche%20%28architecture%29">niches</a> designed by Ira Lake and A. Fortescue Duguid. Each contain a marble slab under a gothic <a href="blind%20arch">blind arch</a> topped with a <a href="Glossary%20of%20architecture%23G">gablet</a> and <a href="finial">finial</a>, and decorated with various badges and insignia, including those of, on the <a href="molding%20%28decorative%29">moulding</a>s: Canada's 178 pre-1914 militia regiments; in the pierced <a href="quatrefoil">quatrefoil</a> panels: cavalry, and non-infantry field units; in the <a href="Diaper%20%28architecture%29">diaper</a> background: pre-Confederation French and British regiments and colonial forces; on the gablet <a href="crocket">crocket</a>s: reinforced battalions; on the gablet <a href="Springer%20%28architecture%29">springers</a>: all branches of the Canadian Corps; on the arch quatrefoil and cusps: Badges and insignia of Canada's 178 pre-1914 militia regiments: The Royal Canadian Dragoons, Lord Strathcona's Horse (Royal Canadians), The Governor General's Body Guard, 1st Hussars, 2nd Dragoons, 3rd The Prince of Wales' Canadian Dragoons; on the arch <a href="spandrel">spandrel</a>s: medals and war decorations of the allied countries; on the shield: coats of arms appropriate to the relevant historical context; and on the low relief panel: historical scenes of Canadians during World War I. The marble panels themselves originally described the various campaigns and battles in the theatres of war between 1914 and 1918. These, however, were replaced in 1982 with panels illustrating the Canadian Forces' engagements from the <a href="Fenian%20Raids">Fenian Raids</a> to the <a href="Korean%20War">Korean War</a>, along with excerpts from the Bible, poems, and other literature.
Windows.
After John Pearson canvassed British artists in stained glass for designs for the Memorial Chamber's windows, he settled on Frank S.J. Hollister of Toronto for the task; Hollister's proposal was presented in 1925 to the <a href="Public%20Works%20and%20Government%20Services%20Canada">Department of Public Works</a> for the <a href="Queen-in-Council">Governor-in-Council</a>'s approval. Each of the three 7 m by 3.5 m windows is divided into vertical quadrants by stone mullions and contain <a href="Allegory">allegorical</a> figures amongst heraldic symbols, including the Royal Arms of Canada, the arms of each of the provinces, and those of the United Kingdom.
This window displays four allegories: "Victory", as a woman holding a crown and surrounded by a <a href="Laurel%20wreath">laurel</a> branch and a helmet on a shield; "Labour", a male figure amongst objects such as a shovel, spinning wheel, and <a href="astrolabe">astrolabe</a>, with the motto "Fortitudo Industria et Pax" (Strength Industry and Peace); "Progress", a man holding a book and quill, surrounded by a celestial crown, <a href="weighing%20scale">weighing scale</a>s, <a href="hourglass">hourglass</a>, and <a href="galley">galley</a>; and "Science", a male holding a microscope and flask, amongst symbols such as a globe and torch, all below a ribbon indicating metallurgy, mineralogy, and chemistry. These four figures are arranged above four lower panels, the first showing three inscriptions: "THANKS BE TO GOD WHO GIVE THUS THE VICTORY", from 1 Corinthians 15:57, "FAITH UNTO DEATH", and "ACQUIT YE LIKE MEN BE STRONG", both from 1 Corinthians 16:13. Also in this section is a crowd of people bearing shields and spears, who represent the people of Canada uniting in response to the call of the man shown in the second panel, who holds a sword and trumpet, calling "To Arms"; at his side is a child holding flowers, representing faith and courage. This section also displays the words "THOU HAST GIRDED ME WITH STRENGTH UNTO THE BATTLE", from Psalm 18:39. In the third panel stands a woman supporting a rod entwined with winged serpents, the <a href="Rod%20of%20Asclepius">Rod of Asclepius</a>, characterising the nurses of battle, and below her is the phrase "TRUE WORTH THAT NEVER KNOWS IGNOBLE DEFEAT SHINES WITH UNDIMMED GLORY", taken from <a href="Odes%20%28Horace%29">Horace's Odes</a>. The fourth bay displays a group of men and horses congregating from farms, offices, and factories, while a fleet of ships rests at bay awaiting the men to carry them to war.
This is the south window, the first panel of which shows the <a href="Michael%20%28archangel%29">archangel Michael</a> holding a trumpet, representing the call to battle, and, above his head, a seated woman with children at her knee, symbolising the sacrifices of women and children in the name of liberty, honour, and justice, while in the lower portion an armoured figure bears the Crown of Victory in his hands. The second panel contains the inscriptions: "AT THE GOING DOWN OF THE SUN AND IN THE MORNING WE WILL REMEMBER THEM", taken from the work of <a href="Laurence%20Binyon">Laurence Binyon</a>, and "FREEDOM IS THE SURE POSSESSION OF THOSE ALONE WHO HAVE COURAGE TO DEFEND IT", from <a href="Pericles">Pericles</a>, as well as, in the lower portion, an armoured figure holding a <a href="Torch">flambeau</a>, and, in the upper part, <a href="Saint%20George%20and%20the%20Dragon">St. George slaying the dragon</a>. The third panel contains "<a href="Lady%20Justice">Lady Justice</a>" bearing the Scales of Justice and the Great Sword of Judgement, the sword-guard of which shows a figure in a <a href="crucifixion">crucifixion</a> pose—representing suffering for both the victors and the defeated—and below her the words "JUSTITIA LIBERTAS PERPETUO" (Justice Liberty in Perpetuity). Beneath Lady Justice in this panel is the heroic figure of Canada wearing armour and helmet and holding the laurel wreath of victory, but looking mournfully at the Book of Remembrance, and behind her are two other persons, one symbolising Canadian motherhood and the other <a href="First%20Nations%20in%20Canada">First Nations</a>. The fourth quadrant shows <a href="Joan%20of%20Arc">Joan of Arc</a> bearing a shield and standing before the <a href="National%20Emblem%20of%20France">royal coat of arms of France</a>.
Similar to the other windows, this one shows four figures across the top portion. The first of these is the figure of the "Victory of Peace", holding both a palm branch and the sword of judgement, while a dove flies overhead. The second person shown is that of "Prosperity", who holds a wheat sheaf and a sicle, and, next to him, is "Progress", bearing a winged wheel and with the Lamp of Knowledge above his head. The fourth figure is "Plenty", symbolising the replenishment of both material and spirit through noble pursuit. Arranged in the lower portion of the window is a crowd of people assembled in peace and led by three figures in the foreground and bearing the symbols of their trades: "Industry" holds a <a href="mallet">mallet</a> and <a href="dynamo">dynamo</a>, "Agriculture" bears a <a href="scythe">scythe</a>, "Honour" carries a torch inscribed with words from <a href="John%20McCrae">John McCrae</a>'s poem "<a href="In%20Flanders%20Fields">In Flanders Fields</a>": "BE THE TORCH YOURS TO HOLD IT HIGH", and "Motherhood", who is surrounded by children. At the base of the second and third panels are the phrases: "HE MAKETH WARS TO CEASE", from Psalm 46:9, and "JUDGEMENT SHALL RETURN UNTO RIGHTEOUSNESS", from Psalm 94:15.
Carillon.
Accompanying the Peace Tower clock is a 53-bell <a href="carillon">carillon</a>, conceived by an act of parliament as a commemoration of the <a href="Armistice%20with%20Germany%20%28Compi%C3%A8gne%29">1918 armistice</a> that ended World War 1 and was inaugurated on 1 July 1927, the 60th anniversary of <a href="Canadian%20Confederation">Confederation</a>. The <a href="Bourdon%20%28bell%29">bourdon</a> ('largest') bell weighs and the smallest weighs . They encompass a <a href="Range%20%28music%29">range</a> of 4.5 <a href="octaves">octaves</a> on the keyboard. All 53 bells were cast and tuned by <a href="Gillett%20%26amp%3B%20Johnston">Gillett & Johnston</a>, a <a href="bell%20foundry">bell foundry</a> based in <a href="Croydon">Croydon</a>, <a href="England">England</a>. The Dominion Carillonneur plays both regular recitals on the carillon and tolls the bells to mark major occasions such as <a href="state%20funeral">state funeral</a>s and <a href="Remembrance%20Day%23Canada">Remembrance Day</a>. Each bell is stationary and is struck by its internal clapper, itself mechanically linked to the carillon keyboard, to create a note, a particular one on the music scale for each bell. In this way, the carillon plays similarly to a piano, allowing the carillonneur to change the sounds by varying the way he or she strikes the keys.
History.
Coming immediately after the destruction of the parliament buildings by fire in 1916, the Peace Tower's conception coincided with the end of the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a>. With this in mind, <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Robert%20Borden">Robert Borden</a> dedicated the site of the tower on 1 July 1917, with the words: "[the tower will be a] memorial to the debt of our forefathers and to the valour of those Canadians who, in the Great War, fought for the liberties of Canada, of the Empire, and of humanity." Two years later, the Peace Tower's cornerstone was laid by Prince Edward, Prince of Wales (later King <a href="Edward%20VIII">Edward VIII</a>), during his wider <a href="Royal%20tours%20of%20Canada">royal tour of Canada</a> on September 1, 1919, and the structure was <a href="Topping%20out">topped out</a> in 1922.
In the summer of 1925, an informal ceremony was held in the Memorial Chamber, where in <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20Canada">Governor General of Canada</a> <a href="Julian%20Byng%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Byng%20of%20Vimy">the Viscount Byng of Vimy</a>; Prime Minister <a href="William%20Lyon%20Mackenzie%20King">William Lyon Mackenzie King</a>; Leader of <a href="Official%20Opposition%20%28Canada%29">His Majesty's Loyal Opposition</a> <a href="Arthur%20Meighen">Arthur Meighen</a>; and the Commander-in-Chief of the British forces during World War I, <a href="Douglas%20Haig%2C%201st%20Earl%20Haig">the Earl Haig</a>, laid the base stones of the clustered marble columns that support the fan vault ceiling. The Prince of Wales then returned to Ottawa again in 1927 to dedicate the <a href="altar">altar</a> of the Memorial Chamber and to inaugurate the Dominion Carillon, the first playing of which on that day was heard by listeners across the country on the first ever coast-to-coast radio broadcast in Canada. Upon completion, the Peace Tower stood as the tallest building in Ottawa as well as the whole of Canada.
Starting in 1994, the Peace Tower was covered and the accessible spaces closed for a two-year conservation project aimed at reversing deterioration of the masonry and preventing further moisture penetration. However, the machinery of the clock was not within the scope of work and, on 24 May 2006, the clock stopped for the first time in 28 years, with the display inactive at 7:28 for about one day.
